Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Guala, Michelle
Proposal Number: 1351303

The focus of this CAREER project is to use concepts from passive/active flow control from the field of aerodynamics in order to control flow-surface interactions at the geophysical scale. The large characteristic scales of natural landscapes are found to overlap with the very large scale structures of the turbulent flow that continuously reshape the confining landscape (such as flow of rivers, ocean streams, or wind). The PI proposes to explore the relationship between the large scales of turbulent flows and the evolution of an erodible topography, and then to use this knowledge along with flow control concepts to shape natural topography, introducing the concept of Geophysical Flow Control (GFC).
Intellectual Merit:
Flow control has been extensively used in aeronautics to control laminar to turbulent flow transition on airfoils, or to alter the structure of turbulent boundary layers through perturbations of the boundary conditions. In many geophysical flows, the observed large scale patterns result from flow instabilities somewhat different from those governing turbulent wall-bounded flows. The PI proposes to extend the flow control approach to the case of meandering flows in natural or built environments, aiming at achieving specific flow or topographic patterns. By identifying the intrinsic instabilities of a natural dynamical system and by understanding their governing mechanism one can selectively dampen these instabilities and control their effects. Geophysical flow control will be validated through specific benchmark experiments.

Broader Impacts:

Successful completion of the project will enable the control of the formation and evolution of meandering patterns affecting the economy of entire communities in coastal or fluvial environments. Fundamental knowledge generated through this project can affect river and estuarine restoration projects, as well as the process of harnessing energy in river flows with the deployment of marine hydrokinetic turbines at the appropriate locations.
The educational plan is to construct a movable GFC demonstration model that can be used, for example, at the Minnesota Stare Fair or in K-12 tours. It also includes the establishment of an open competition for a remotely-controlled experiment and a virtual field experiment. The ongoing outreach activities at St. Anthony Falls Laboratory at the University of Minnesota will be utilized to bring exposure of the educational activities of the project to students and the public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has been focused on the interactions between renewable energy converters, turbulent flows and erodible channels. The approach has evolved to include experiments in different sand bedded channels, with hydrokinetic turbines of different size, shape and operating condition, as well as theoretical models.

The complexity of the problem required a systematic investigation of the salient physical mechanisms governing such interaction: 1) the incoming flow perceived by the turbines has been investigated in different settings using the canonical turbulent boundary layer over rough wall as a model for river flows; 2) the formation, migration and deformation of river bedforms has been studied and a hierarchy of models to estimate the traveling velocity of ripples and dunes of different sizes was proposed; both rough wall turbulence and bedform propagation have been investigated using experiments at the laboratory and field scales to confirm old scaling laws and propose new ones; 3) the performance and wake of horizontal axis turbines have been measured and analyzed using wind tunnel, field measurements and channel flow experiments to quantify the velocity deficit, directly linked to potential spacing in a multi turbine power plant, and the unsteady meandering of the wake, impacting control and power fluctuations of downstream units; 4)  the erosion and depositional patterns generated by a single turbine have been documented extensively leading to an elegant model estimating the maximum scour depth that can hopefully guide foundation design and future deployments.

These were the necessary ingredients to build experimental capabilities and knowledge to tackle the problem in its full complexity, i.e. what happens if a multi turbine power plant is deployed in a river? We used the largest flume at the St. Anthony Falls Laboratory  and state of the art measuring technique to run repeated experiments with continuous sediment transport and 12 hydrokinetic turbine models. First, we demonstrated that large dunes approaching the turbines become distorted as they approach the rotor avoiding any dangerous collision between the evolving river bed and the rotating blades. This was crucial to confirm the resilience of the power plan under flood conditions.

Second, we demonstrated that the layout of the turbines is critical and that the flume width should be only marginally blocked, to avoid the generation of long, alternated scour deposition patterns propagating downstream of the river. This is a very important aspect connecting genuine morphodynamic processes governing bars and meanders formation with the obstruction due to turbine arrays. We confirmed this result using porous grids of different size, width extension and elevation. A model has been developed to relate the turbine operating condition and layout, all contributing to the overall drag and partial obstruction in the river cross section, to predict the long term disturbance an hydrokinetic power plant deployment may induce in the river.

This ongoing investigation led to a more holistic vision of renewable energy extraction in the environment. Rivers and estuaries are not perfect systems under current anthropogenic effects: dams, hydraulic structures, stream bank erosion and stream rectification may all contribute to some non-equilibrium configuration in erodible channel beds resulting in the alteration of fluvial ecosystems. Both design and deployment strategies of new energy converters should therefore account for the interactions with the river bed , not to limit the environmental impact, but to actually improve the existing conditions. A few examples: a turbine rotor in yawed conditions allows controlling the sediments evolution in the wake and directing, to some extent, the deposit towards the stream bank. The combination of wake and deposit deflection of a multi turbine deployment could prevent bank erosion and induce a positive environmental impact; a Vane-like deploymet of hydrokinetic turbines extending to half width could be used instead  to trigger the onset of river meandering to reduce the energy slope, and renaturalize a stream; a new patented, in bank, drag turbine has been designed, experimentally tested and improved through numerical simulations to reduce shear stress in the wake, along the side wall, in addition to efficiently generate energy, achieving both goals of bank protection and renewable energy production.

In summary, this project allowed me and two graduated PhD students to explore most of the key aspects of renewable energy systems in geophysical flow environments: from wind turbines in the atmospheric surface layer to hydrokinetic turbines in rivers. The major outcomes are not only in the applied research frameworks of sustainable deployment of energy converters and river bathymetry control, but also in the fundamental aspects governing turbulent flows, erosional and depositional mechanisms, and wakes.
